newsitem.title: USA: Netscape, Oracle in Internet software pact.
newsitem.headline: Netscape, Oracle in Internet software pact.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp. and Oracle Corp., seeking to limit Microsoft Corp.'s efforts to become a dominant provider of Internet software, Monday announced a plan to market each others' products.
The deal combines Netscape's Internet prowess with Oracle's dominance of the database software market, and is likely to give Netscape a boost in the corporate market.

While Netscape's Navigator software is estimated to have as much as 80 percent of the Internet browser market, the Moutain View, Calif.-based company is eager to move into the more lucrative corporate market.

The alliance brings together Oracle's Universal Server family of database software products and so-called Network Computer products, with Netscape's commercial applications for the Internet and its market-leading Netscape Navigator browser.

"While we are enormous proponents of supporting all client technologies, there are times when it's more appropriate to select a closer alliance partner," said Oracle Chairman Larry Ellison. "We've chosen to work with Netscape."
Network computers, or NCs, are stripped-down versions of personal computers that are expected to sell for a fraction of what a standard computer costs.
Oracle, bsaed in Redwood Shores, Calif., and Sun Microsystems Inc. have been leading proponents of the network computer, and Sun is expected to unveil a line of NCs Tuesday.
Microsoft, which until recently had dismissed the network computer, Monday announced a new push for inexpensive, easy-to-use personal computers, dubbed the NetPC.
Unlike the personal computer, which relies on operating system software to run its programmes, the network computer uses Internet technology to access software from large servers.

Industry analysts said a widespread switch to the network computer from the PC would hurt Microsoft because the software giant relies on sales of its Windows operating system for part of its strong growth.

Microsoft and Netscape are currently locked in a battle for control of the software market for the Internet and the more lucrative market for intranets, or corporate networks based on Internet standards.
Netscape stock was up $1.125 at $47.375 in afternoon trading on Nasdaq, while was up 31.25 cents at $42.625.
